{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3411363,"name":"sam liu","username":"catrix","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/dbc845/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-26T07:55:29.475Z","cooked":"

I am running 6328’s Advance Swerve Drive Example on a robotRIO1.0

Screenshot 2024-07-26 0321271322×786 29.5 KB

And as you can see, the performance does not look good, during the first 10 seconds after the robot boots, the program is very laggy and if I enable the robot right now, even the closed loops for swerve steers will shake.
The lagging issue disapears after about 30 seconds, when the program is “warmed up”. But the CPU time still goes to above 20 milli-seconds sometimes, like this:

Screenshot 2024-07-26 0322011341×829 27.1 KB

I add a line in this file that monitors the cpu time of processing cached odometry data from the odometry thread, as well as the total CPU time for Drive.periodic()
Screenshot 2024-07-26 0320491200×334 51.6 KB

image1238×168 18.9 KB

here are the results:

(10 seconds after boot)

Screenshot 2024-07-26 0338551393×921 52.3 KB

(a long time after boot)

Screenshot 2024-07-26 0341291331×901 68.1 KB

and my terminal just keeps telling me look time over-run:

Screenshot 2024-07-26 0343501531×1197 59.2 KB

Did I mess up the program or is it a common issue on robotRIO1.0? I am aware that the CPU of robotRIO1.0 might be too slow. If I still want to use high-frequency odometry and advantagekit at the same time, must I switch to RIO2.0?

Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","username":"Billfred","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-26T11:51:59.333Z","cooked":"

Potentially relevant thread to monitor:

Who Is Able to Use Rio 1.0 Still? (w/ Logging + Swerve + Vision?) Technical Discussion
This past year we switched to using Rio2.0 because our code simply would not run with the memory available on the Rio1.0. I wanted to see if folks out there are still able to run swerve and vision (either LL or PV) with a Rio1.0 and if there are optimizations which allowed you to do so. We have a plethora of Rio1.0, and are not eager to invest in more Rio2.0 with a new system coming in 2027. Any advice on how to continue being able to use Rio1.0, especially for simpler robots for our second te…
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2024-07-26T11:51:59.333Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":178,"readers_count":177,"score":75.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":469168,"topic_slug":"6328s-advanced-swerve-drive-example-lagging-on-robotrio-1-0","display_username":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/who-is-able-to-use-rio-1-0-still-w-logging-swerve-vision/469130","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Who Is Able to Use Rio 1.0 Still? (w/ Logging + Swerve + Vision?)","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":3095,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"says you should come to SCRIW in October"},"post_url":"/t/6328s-advanced-swerve-drive-example-lagging-on-robotrio-1-0/469168/2","custom_user_title":"says you should come to SCRIW in October","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3411435,"name":"Jonah Bonner","username":"jonahb55","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jonahb55/{size}/194474_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-26T17:04:24.932Z","cooked":"

There are a few things to unpack here, but in general it is definitely possible for a RIO 1 to run moderately complex projects like this. I know of several teams running variations of this example project on the RIO 1 without issue.

catrix:

during the first 10 seconds after the robot boots, the program is very laggy

This is to be expected with almost any Java robot project, since the JVM needs to warm up. How long the loop times take to settle down depends on the project and the GC settings you use, but anywhere from 10 to 30 seconds (as well as shortly after the first enable) is typical.

catrix:

even the closed loops for swerve steers will shake

As a slight tangent, the AdvantageKit project is set up to run PID controllers on the RIO rather than the motor controllers. This is absolutely a viable control scheme (we ran it with no issues on our 2023 competition robot), but running control loops on the motor controller can improve stability in case of loop overruns. The AdvantageKit project is only intended to be used as a starting point, and there are many examples of teams running on-controller PID with AdvantageKit.

If you’re only seeing this issue while the JVM is still warming up, I wouldn’t worry about it much though.

catrix:

But the CPU time still goes to above 20 milli-seconds sometimes

Occasional loop overruns in the ~20-40ms range generally aren’t an issue. When analyzing loop overruns, I find it particularly helpful to use AdvantageScope’s statistics tab. For example, here are the loop cycle times (the “full” loop cycle) during one of our 2024 Einstein matches:

Screenshot 2024-07-26 at 12.54.53 PM1894×528 38.7 KB

The vast majority of loop cycles are in the 8ms to 13ms range, and the 99% percentile is 12.4ms. However, we have regular spikes above 20ms without issue:

Screenshot 2024-07-26 at 12.55.59 PM2290×1000 187 KB

Generally loop overruns are only an issue if they are very large or occurring on a significant portion of cycles. Ultimately, it depends whether they actually affect the robot’s functionality (as I said before, running on-RIO PID makes the code a bit more sensitive). If you aren’t seeing issues as a result of the occasional ~30ms overrun, there’s no reason to be concerned about it; this is usually the stance we take with our competition code.

catrix:

my terminal just keeps telling me look time over-run

The current system that WPILib uses to report loop overruns unfortunately lacks subtly in conveying which overruns are critical or not. Flooding the console with every overrun is not particularly helpful to the user, since most of these warnings can be safely ignored (for the reasons I just described). We are working on alternatives that will improve this experience in future years.
